docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks for all the great posts from readers - you've given me a lot to chew on, and there are many questions and comments I plan to address in future posts. But for today, I want to look briefly at the "elitism" issue raised by several of you. As you will see it also ties into the good question raised by Paul Stamler about whether consumer action - voting with your forks - is adequate to the task of changing the American way of eating.

headline.seo: Talking Points: Readers Respond to The Big, Fat American Kid Crisis . . . And 10 Things We Should Do About It '
headline.main: Readers Respond to 'The Big, Fat American Kid Crisis . . . And 10 Things We Should Do About It '

docs.lead_paragraph: Dawn, Queens, N.Y.: I was delighted and surprised to read that at least one state, Arkansas, has mandated a daily exercise break for employees, a measure I hadn't expected to encounter outside my own wishful daydreams. Removing junk foods and offering healthy snacks in schools are wonderful ideas.However, these and other state regulations protecting the public are under attack. Big Food and large corporations are promoting legislation that would strike down any state regulation that exceeds federal requirements. The Food Uniformity Act would ensure that consumers in every state were uniformly ignorant of any information not approved by industry lobbyists in Washington. Are your federal representatives willing to override your state government's more enlightened consumer regulations? This might be a good time find out and ask them why.

headline.seo: Talking Points: The Big, Fat American Kid Crisis . . .
headline.main: The Big, Fat American Kid Crisis . . . and 10 Things We Should Do About It

docs.lead_paragraph: We should encourage young people to take responsibility for their weight and health. But we should also start to consider childhood obesity a social problem, and take action as a nation.
docs.snippet: We should encourage young people to take responsibility for their weight and health. But we should also start to consider childhood obesity a social problem, and take action as a nation.

headline.print_headline: Heavy People May Beat Critical Illness More Often
headline.main: Outcomes: Heavy People May Beat Critical Illness More Often

docs.lead_paragraph: A recent study suggests that some people who are very overweight may be more likely to survive a critical illness than people who are in better shape.
docs.snippet: A recent study suggests that some people who are very overweight may be more likely to survive a critical illness than people who are in better shape.
